course.subject: ENVS
course.name: Environmental Conservation
course.description: This course covers the essential topics of environmental conservation, which includes biodiversity, ecosystems, environmental ethics and economics, environmental policy, resource management, and conservation biology. Case studies from Hong Kong and other regions will be investigated. For LIFS and ENVS students in their third or fourth year of study only.
course.prerequisites: LIFS 2060 AND LIFS 3160

reviews.author: scientist123
reviews.comment_content: The course content is too general and common sense, most of the knowledge is common sense.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Dr Ko is teaching a bit too slow, that she stops every point and elaborates a lot. depends on whether you like her teaching style or not but I don't really like it.
Cindy and Stanley are both reading the powerpoint from the screen and it is no meaning to attend their lectures.
reviews.comment_workload: there is midterm final and group project and also quizzes. the group project is a bit heavy in workload

reviews.author: yooooooooo
reviews.title: Worth to study
reviews.comment_content:
Same as the course name, it is about conservation of environment. They are easy to understand (even for me as a minor student) and interesting.

The format is in lecture (include guest lecture[GL]), field trips

Topic:
- Marine Conservation in HK [GL]
- Habitat Destruction and Fragmentation
- Species Invasion
- Mercy Release
- Mangrove Conservation
- Herpetofauna of Hong Kong and their conservation [GL]
- Mudflat Conservation
- Protected Areas
- Trade-in Endangered Species (CITES) [GL]
- Overexploitation
- Conservation of Sha Lo Tung [GL]
- Mitigation and Restoration Ecology
- Conservation of Chinese White Dolphin [GL]
- Roles of Zoos and Aquariums
- Eco-shorelines
- Oyster reef conservation [GL]

4 Field trips
- Ting Kok
- Sha Lo Tung
- HK Zoological and Botanical Garden
- Pak Nai
reviews.comment_teaching: If you have taken Cindy and Cynthia's lessons, then you should know how they teach.
reviews.comment_grading:
Because it is still an online teaching, so
Final Exam: 40%
Essay: 20%
Participation (GL& field trip): 40%

Final Exam includes MC and 3 long Qs (base on the information given and apply your knowledge to answer).

Mean = 66.41
SD : 9.07

I got 0.8SD above the mean, and it is not difficult to get high marks in the essays and assignments (just answer all the questions in essay form). The final grade is B+.
reviews.comment_workload:
Because it is online teaching and exam, so participation accounts for 40%. And you see, there are Guest lectures and field trips.

One-page summary per one guest lecture, two-page report per one field trip. Cynthia and Cindy give us enough time to write, but you know... the workload is high.

They said that because it is hard to include contents in guest lectures into exam questions, so they change them to assignment.

Around 1000-1200 words for the final essay. The topic is decided by you. If you really cannot think of one, they will give you one, but the topics might be difficult, ha~

reviews.author: 淺水健
reviews.title: a disappointed course
reviews.comment_content: just similar to the 2, 3 heading number courses. The content are common senses not technical things.  And they will not teach deeply on each topics.
reviews.comment_teaching: instructors teaching style similar to other Ocean dept. courses, nothing special. But the guest lectures were mostly very boring letting me fell asleep in the classes.
reviews.comment_workload: very high, there are many guest lecture and field trip you have to attend. Each field trip spent you a whole day to let you observed the site. After field trips and guest lectures you have to write essays to summary what you have learn and opinion of relative environmental issues. And you have to finish a 1000 words essay in conservation disciplines. In this course I have to write about 6000 to 7000 words in all these annoying tasks.

reviews.author: YSA
reviews.title: Awesome course, interesting topics and good lectures, fair grading, very little workload apart from memorization.
reviews.comment_content:
Very interesting course about several different conservation theories and strategies, using examples of specific animals from HK and other regions around the world.

Topics:

Human Population and the Environment
Conservation of Microbial Resources
Conservation of Horseshoe Crabs
Genetic Basis of Conservation Biology
Habitat Destruction
Habitat Fragmentation and Landscape Change
Conservation of Chinese White Dolphins
Conservation of Corals in Hong Kong
Environmental Degradation and Pollution
Species invasion
Overharvesting and Fisheries Conservation
Mudflats Conservation
Merit Release
Case Study: Birds of Paradise
How to Choose Species to Protect
How to Choose Habitats to Protect
Environmental Ethics

The topics are not too difficult, and link well with each other. Despite 3 different professors, it is easy to follow the lectures.

No background is absolutely required to do well in this course, but LIFS 2060 and LIFS 3160 are very useful.

Highly recommend this course as an elective for anyone.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Stanley is a great lecturer, he explains every topic clearly and slowly, always open to questions. Detailed lecture notes.

Cindy's lectures are a bit boring, and sometimes confusing as a lot of the things she says are very different or conflicting with the lecture notes. The notes are not sufficient for exam revision.

Ice explains things very fast and tries to cover a lot of topics, similar to her other courses like LIFS 3160. She is nice, as long as you don't mess with her by disturbing or entering late. Clear and very detailed lecture notes.
reviews.comment_grading:
Midterm: 45%
Final: 45%
Group project: 10%

Midterm and final have MCQs and a few long questions. The MCQ are straightforward if you just memorize all the lecture notes. The long questions can be a little tricky, require some more time and deeper thinking.

Midterm mean = 16/30
Final mean = ?? not sure if it was released

I got 0.7 SD above mean in midterm, don't know about final and group project but probably close to mean. Final grade = B+
reviews.comment_workload:
This course is basically a LIFS course. The main workload is  just a lot of memorization for the midterm and final (300-400 slides in total for each exam).

The group project is at the end of the semester. Just a 5-minute and 5-slides presentation in a group of 3 people, so less than 2 minutes/slides per person. Very easy and quick.
